Children.Text: This wizard will take you through the steps of creating a broadcaster. You can specify every property and connection and it will create a script definition at the end of the process that you then can paste into your `onInit` callback.

Children.Help: The ID will be used to create the script variable definition as well as act as a unique ID for every broadcaster of a single script processor. The name must be a valid HiseScript identifier.
A comment that is shown in the broadcaster map and helps with navigation & code organisation

Enter a comma separated list of strings that will be used as tags for the broadcaster. This lets you filter which broadcaster you want to show on the broadcaster map and is useful for navigating complex projects
The colour of the broadcaster in the broadcaster map

Children.Text:
Please select the event type that you want to attach the broadcaster to. There are multiple event sources which can trigger a broadcaster message.

This will create a script line calling one of the `attachToXXX()` functions that hook up the broadcaster to an event source.

Children.Help: No event source. Use this option if you want to call the broadcaster manually or attach it to any other script callback slot (eg. TransportHandler callbacks).

An event of a complex data object (Tables, Slider Packs or AudioFiles). This can be either:

- content changes (eg. when loading in a new sample)
- a display index change (eg. if the table ruler is moved)
Script properties of a UI component selection (eg. the `visible` property).
The value of a component. This will register the broadcaster as additional value callback that will be fired whenever the control callback will be executed.

The visibility of a UI component.

>This also takes into account the visibility of parent components so it's a more reliable way than listen to the component's `visible` property.
Adds a popup menu when the UI component is clicked.
Listens to band add / delete, reset events of a parametriq EQ.
Listens to changes of a module attribute (when calling `setAttribute()`, eg. the **Reverb Width** or **Filter Frequency**
Mouse events for a UI component selection
Listens to changes of the processing specifications (eg. sample rate of audio buffer size)
Listens to button clicks within a given radio group ID\n> This is especially useful for implementing your page switch logic
Listens to changes of the routing matrix (the channel routing configuration) of a module.

Children.Text:
### No source

You can use a broadcaster without attaching it to a event source. In this case, please add a comma separated list of argument IDs that you want this broadcaster to use.

Children.Help: This is a comma separated list of arguments and will define how many data slots the broadcaster will have. This property will also define how many arguments a listener callback is supposed to have.

Children.Text:
### Complex Type

Attaching a broadcaster to a complex data object lets you listen to table edit changes or playback position updates of one or multiple data sources. Please fill in the information below to proceed to the next step.

Children.Help: The data type that you want to listen to

The event type you want to listen to.

-**Content** events will be triggered whenever the data changes (so eg. loading a new sample or editing a table will trigger this event).
-**DisplayIndex** events will occur whenever the read position changes (so the playback position in the audio file or the table ruler in the table).

Children.EmptyText: Enter module IDs as shown in the Patch Browser...
Children.Help: The ID of the module that you want to listen to. You can also listen to multiple modules at once, in this case just enter every ID separated by a comma

The slot index of the complex data object that you want to listen to.

> Some modules have multiple complex data objects (eg. the table envelope has two tables for the attack and release phase so if you want to listen to the release table, you need to pass in `1` here.
The metadata that will be shown on the broadcaster map.

Children.Text:
### Component Properties

Attaches the broadcaster to changes of the script properties like `enabled`, `text`, etc.

> If you want to listen to visibility changes, take a look at the **ComponentVisibility** attachment mode, which also takes the visibility of parent components into account.

Children.EmptyText: Enter component IDs as shown in the Component List...
Children.Help: A comma-separated list of all component IDs that you want to listen to.
The property you want to listen to. You can also use a comma-separated list for multiple properties
The metadata that will be shown on the broadcaster map.

Children.Text:
### Component Value

This attachment mode will register the broadcaster to control callbacks of a Component.

Children.EmptyText: Enter component IDs as shown in the Component List...
Children.Help: A comma-separated list of all component IDs that you want to listen to.
The metadata that will be shown on the broadcaster map.

Children.Text:
### Component Visibility

This mode attaches the broadcaster to whether the component is actually shown on the interface, which also takes into account the parent visibility and whether its bounds are within the parent's dimension

Children.EmptyText: Enter component IDs as shown in the Component List...
Children.Help: A comma-separated list of all components that you want to listen to.
The metadata that will be shown on the broadcaster map.

Children.Text:
### Context Menu

This attach mode will show a context menu when you click on the registered UI components and allow you to perform additional actions.

Children.EmptyText: Enter component IDs as shown in the Component List...
Children.Help: A comma-separated list of all components that you want to listen to.
A function name that will be created by the template generator to query the active and ticked state of each context menu item.

This will define the items that are shown in the list (one item per new line). You can use the markdown-like syntax to create sub menus, separators and headers known from the other Context menu builders in HISE (ScriptPanel, SubmenuCombobox)...
If this is true, the context menu will be shown when you click on the UI element with the left mouse button, otherwise it will require a right click to show up.
The metadata that will be shown on the broadcaster map.

Children.Text:
### EQ Events

This attachment mode will register one or more Parametriq EQ modules to the broadcaster and will send events when EQ bands are added / removed.

> This does not cover the band parameter changes, as this can be queried with the usual module parameter attachment mode.

Children.EmptyText: Enter module IDs as shown in the Patch Browser...
Children.Help: The ID of the module that you want to listen to. You can also listen to multiple modules at once, in this case just enter every ID separated by a comma

Set the event type that the broadcaster should react too. This can be multiple items from this list:

- `BandAdded`
- `BandRemoved`
- `BandSelected`
- `FFTEnabled`
The metadata that will be shown on the broadcaster map.

Children.Text:
### Module Parameters

Attaches the broadcaster to attribute changes of one or more modules.

Children.EmptyText: Enter module IDs as shown in the Patch Browser...
Children.Help: The ID of the module that you want to listen to. You can also listen to multiple modules at once, in this case just enter every ID separated by a comma
The parameters that you want to listen to. This can be either the actual parameter names or the indexes of the parameters
The metadata that will be shown on the broadcaster map.

Children.Text:
### Mouse Events

This attachment mode will cause the broadcaster to fire at certain mouse callback events (just like the ScriptPanel's `mouseCallback`).

Children.EmptyText: Enter component IDs as shown in the Component List...
Children.Help: A comma-separated list of all components that you want to listen to.
The callback level that determines when the broadcaster will send a message
Children.Items:
No Callbacks
Context Menu
Clicks Only
Clicks & Hover
Clicks, Hover & Dragging
All Callbacks

Children.Help: The metadata that will be shown on the broadcaster map.

Children.Text:
### Processing specs

This will attach the broadcaster to changes of the audio processing specs (sample rate, buffer size, etc).

Children.Help: The metadata that will be shown on the broadcaster map.

Children.Text:
### Radio Group

This will attach the broadcaster to a radio group (a selection of multiple buttons that are mutually exclusive).

> This is a great way of handling page logic by attaching a broadcaster to a button group and then use its callback to show and hide pages within an array.

Children.Help: The radio group id as it was set as `radioGroup` script property to the buttons that you want to listen to.
The metadata that will be shown on the broadcaster map.

Children.Text:
### Routing Matrix

This attaches the broadcaster to changes in a channel routing of one or more modules (either channel resizes or routing changes including send channel assignments).

Children.EmptyText: Enter module IDs as shown in the Patch Browser...
Children.Help: The ID of the module that you want to listen to. You can also listen to multiple modules at once, in this case just enter every ID separated by a comma
The metadata that will be shown on the broadcaster map.

Children.Text:
### Target type

Now you can add a target listener which will receive the events caused by the event source specified on the previous page.

Children.Help: Skip the creation of a target callback.
A script function that will be executed immediately when the event occurs.
A script function that will be executed with a given delay after the event occurred.
This will change a component property based on a customizeable function that must calculate and return the value
Simply sends out a component refresh method (eg. `repaint()`) to its registered components.
This sets the value of a component
This will sync the given module parameter to the last argument of the broadcaster.

Children.Text:
### Callback

This will call a function with a customizeable `this` object.

Children.Help: You can specify any HiseScript expression that will be used as `this` object in the function.
This will use the given function as an ID. Leave this empty in order to create an inplace anonymous function.
The metadata that will be shown on the broadcaster map.

Children.Text:
### Delayed Callback

This will call a script function with a delay.

Children.Help: You can specify any HiseScript expression that will be used as `this` object in the function.
This will use the given function as an ID. Leave this empty in order to create an inplace anonymous function.
The delay time in milliseconds
The metadata that will be shown on the broadcaster map.

Children.Text:
### Component Property

This will set one or more component properties of one or more components to a given value. You can supply a custom function that will calculate a value for each target, otherwise the value of the broadcaster is used.

> This is eg. useful if you just want to sync (forward) some property changes to other components.

Children.EmptyText: Enter component IDs as shown in the Component List...
Children.Help: A comma-separated list of all component IDs that you want to listen to.
The property you want to listen to. You can also use a comma-separated list for multiple properties
This will use the given function as an ID. Leave this empty in order to create an inplace anonymous function.
The metadata that will be shown on the broadcaster map.

Children.Text:
### Component Refresh

This will send out an update message to the specified components

Children.EmptyText: Enter component IDs as shown in the Component List...
Children.Help: A comma-separated list of all component IDs that you want to listen to.

The type of refresh message that should be sent:

- `repaint`: causes a component repaint message (and if the component is a panel, it will also call its paint routine)
- `changed`: causes a value change callback that will fire the component's `setValue()` callback
- `updateValueFromProcessorConnection`: updates the component from the current processor's value (if it is connected via `processorId` and `parameterId`).
- `loseFocus`: will lose the focus of the keyboard (if the component has currently the keyboard focus).
- `resetValueToDefault`: will reset the component to its default (as defined by the `defaultValue` property). Basically the same as a double click.
The metadata that will be shown on the broadcaster map.

Children.Text:
### Component Value

This will cause a value change alongside with a control callback for the given components. The value that is send to the components can be customized with a function, otherwise it will use the broadcaster's value (if applicable).

Children.EmptyText: Enter component IDs as shown in the Component List...
Children.Help: A comma-separated list of all component IDs that you want to listen to.
This will use the given function as an ID. Leave this empty in order to create an inplace anonymous function.
The metadata that will be shown on the broadcaster map.

Children.Text:
### Module Parameter

Attaching this as listener will send the last argument of the broadcaster as parameter change to the given module.

Children.Help: The ID of the module that you want to send the parameter change to.
A single parameter (either an integer or the parameter ID) that should be set for the given module
The metadata that will be shown on the broadcaster map.

Children.Text: Press Finished in order to copy the code below to the clipboard (you can make some manual adjustments before).
